questions.text: A patient was admitted with complaints of tachycardia, arrhythmias. On examination, multiple scratch marks were present over the body. Probable drug of abuse in above patient is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine

 

Cocaine is a powerful sympathomimetic drug that stimulates the central nervous system, leading to symptoms such as tachycardia (rapid heart rate) and arrhythmias (irregular heartbeats). One of the distinctive signs of cocaine abuse is the presence of multiple scratch marks on the body. This occurs due to tactile hallucinations, commonly referred to as "cocaine bugs" or "formication/ Magnan Symptoms" where the user feels as though insects are crawling on or under their skin, causing them to scratch incessantly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morphine: Morphine is a central nervous system depressant, not a stimulant. It typically causes bradycardia (slow heart rate) rather than tachycardia or arrhythmias. It also does not produce tactile hallucinations or scratch marks.

 

Option C. Datura: Although Datura can cause tachycardia and arrhythmias due to its anticholinergic properties, it is not commonly known as a drug of abuse. Moreover, Datura does not typically cause the tactile hallucinations that result in scratch marks.

 

Option D. Cannabis: Cannabis has minimal physiological effects compared to cocaine. It is unlikely to cause significant tachycardia or arrhythmias. Cannabis also does not cause tactile hallucinations or the resultant scratch marks seen with cocaine use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine abuse can be identified by symptoms of tachycardia, arrhythmias, and the presence of scratch marks due to tactile hallucinations (cocaine bugs).

 

“Cocaine is the drug of abuse”

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who recently lost his wife complains that his intestines have rotted. He believes he is to blame for his wife's death and should be imprisoned. He complains that he is constantly depressed and has lost interest in daily activities since his wife's death. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychotic depression

 

The patient's presentation of severe depressive symptoms (constant depression, anhedonia) combined with delusional beliefs (thinking his intestines have rotted, feeling culpable for his wife's death) is characteristic of psychotic depression. Psychotic depression, or major depressive disorder with psychotic features, is a subtype of major depression characterized by the presence of mood-congruent or mood-incongruent delusions or hallucinations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal grief reaction might involve feelings of sadness and even guilt, but it wouldn't typically involve delusions although transient hallucinations can be seen.

 

Option C. Delusional disorder involves holding one or more delusions in the absence of other psychiatric disorders. These individuals' functioning might not be notably impaired, and the delusions do not typically center around depressive themes.

 

Option D. Schizophrenia involves characteristic symptoms like hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech or behavior, and negative symptoms. While depression can be a feature, the given presentation is more aligned with psychotic depression than with schizophrenia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychotic depression is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e, content of delusion/ hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Delusions in psychotic depression often revolve around themes of guilt, worthlessness, or illness.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 356, 360.

questions.text: Which of the following defects causes familial hypercholesterolemia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDL receptor

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is primarily caused by a defect in the LDL receptor or Apo B100 protein. The LDL receptor plays a crucial role in the regulation of cholesterol levels in the blood by mediating the uptake of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) particles into cells, particularly in the liver. When the LDL receptor is defective or absent, LDL particles cannot be effectively removed from the bloodstream, leading to elevated cholesterol levels, which predispose individuals to atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease. This condition is also known as type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo E: Defects in Apo E are associated with type III hyperlipoproteinemia, not familial hypercholesterolemia. Apo E is important for the clearance of chylomicron remnants and VLDL from the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Apo CII: Apo CII is an activator of lipoprotein lipase, which is essential for the hydrolysis of triglycerides in lipoproteins. Deficiency in Apo CII leads to type I hyperlipoproteinemia (familial hyperchylomicronemia), characterized by elevated chylomicrons and triglycerides, not familial hypercholesterolemia.

 

Option D. Apo B48: Apo B48 is involved in the formation and secretion of chylomicrons from the intestine. It is not related to the development of familial hypercholesterolemia, which involves defects in the LDL receptor or related proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is caused by a defect in the LDL receptor, leading to elevated levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood and increased risk of atherosclerosis.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in double strand DNA break repair mechanism? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MSH2

 

MSH2 stands for "MutS homolog 2." The gene is located on chromosome 2 and is not directly involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. Instead, MSH2 is a key component of the DNA mismatch repair (MMR) pathway. MMR is responsible for correcting errors that occur during DNA replication, such as mismatches and small insertions or deletions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BRCA1: BRCA1 (Breast Cancer 1) is involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks through the homologous recombination pathway. Mutations in the BRCA1 gene are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers.

 

Option C. KU70: KU70, along with KU80, forms the Ku heterodimer (Ku70/Ku80), which is a crucial component of the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) pathway. NHEJ is a major mechanism for repairing double-strand DNA breaks, especially in the G1 phase of the cell cycle.

 

Option D. ATM: The ATM (ataxia-telangiectasia mutated) gene codes for a protein kinase that plays a central role in the cellular response to double-strand DNA breaks. It activates a signaling cascade that leads to DNA repair and cell cycle control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 understand the roles of different genes and proteins in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks (DSBs), which is essential for maintaining genome stability and preventing mutations.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female, on treatment for diabetes for the last 10 years, has experienced three episodes of candidal vulvovaginitis in the last two months. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Canagliflozin

 

Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor, a class of drugs used to treat type 2 diabetes. One of the well-known side effects of SGLT2 inhibitors is an increased risk of fungal infections, particularly candidal infections of the genital tract. This is because SGLT2 inhibitors increase the amount of glucose excreted in the urine, creating an environment conducive to fungal growth. Therefore, in patients with a history of recurrent candidal infections, such as the 60-year-old female in this case, SGLT2 inhibitors like canagliflozin should be avoided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin: The most common side effect of metformin is gastrointestinal upset, particularly diarrhea. It does not increase the risk of fungal infections.

 

Option C. Glipizide: This sulfonylurea drug primarily causes hypoglycemia as a side effect. It does not have a significant association with increased risk of fungal infections.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone: This drug can cause weight gain due to fluid retention but does not increase the risk of fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of recurrent candidal infections, SGLT2 inhibitors, such as canagliflozin, should be avoided due to their association with increased risk of genital fungal infections.

questions.text: Identify the ocular component that originates from neural crest cells. (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Choroid

 

Explanation:

 

The choroid is derived from neural crest cells during embryonic development. Neural crest cells are a special population of cells that originate from the neural tube's edges. During eye development, these cells migrate to form various ocular structures including the choroid, which is the vascular layer between the retina and sclera. The choroid is part of the uveal tract and provides nutrients to the outer retinal layers through its rich vascular network.

 

Note - There is a controversy regarding the correct answer of this question. Our answer is based on Gray's Anatomy, 42nd edition which says "The choroid and sclera differentiate as inner vascular and outer fibrous layers, respectively, from the neural crest mesenchyme that surrounds the optic cup"

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Descemet's membrane: This is not derived from neural crest cells but from neural ectoderm. It's the basement membrane of the corneal endothelium and is secreted by the endothelial cells.
  • Option B. Extraocular muscles: These develop from the mesoderm (specifically from prechordal mesoderm and somitomeres), not from neural crest cells. They include the six muscles that control eye movement.
  • Option C. Vitreous body: This clear gel filling the posterior segment of the eye develops primarily from mesenchymal cells of mesodermal origin, not neural crest cells.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Neural crest cells contribute significantly to ocular development, giving rise to the choroid, corneal endothelium, stroma, melanocytes, ciliary body, and iris stroma, but not to structures like Descemet's membrane, extraocular muscles, or the vitreous body.

questions.text: A patient with O negative and husband B positive delivered a baby. Has received anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks. In which of the following conditions will you give anti-D post-delivery? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Baby +ve, DCT -ve

 

In cases where an Rh-negative mother has delivered a baby, the administration of anti-D immunoglobulin post-delivery is crucial if the baby is Rh-positive and the Direct Coombs Test (DCT) is negative.

 

  • Rh incompatibility: The Rh-negative mother may develop antibodies against Rh-positive fetal red blood cells if fetal-maternal hemorrhage occurs. To prevent this alloimmunization and protect future pregnancies, anti-D immunoglobulin is given to neutralize any fetal Rh-positive red blood cells that might have entered the maternal circulation during delivery.
  • Direct Coombs Test (DCT): This test checks whether antibodies are already attached to the baby's red blood cells. A negative DCT indicates that the fetal RBCs are free of maternal antibodies. If the DCT is negative and the baby is Rh-positive, anti-D is administered to the mother to prevent the formation of antibodies in her system.

 

The administration of anti-D within 72 hours of delivery is standard practice to ensure that any fetal red blood cells in the mother’s circulation are neutralized, thereby preventing Rh sensitization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Baby O negative, DCT negative: In this, anti D is not required as the baby's blood group is Rh negative so there is NO risk of isoimmunization

 

Option B. Baby O negative, DCT positive: In this, anti D is not required as the baby's blood group is Rh negative so there is NO risk of iso immunization

 

Option C. Baby Positive, DCT positive: In this patient although the Baby is Rh positive , but DCT is positive which means Abs have already formed in the mother and hence there is no use of giving her Anti D

 

Educational Objective:

 

Administer anti-D immunoglobulin to an Rh-negative mother after delivery if the baby is Rh-positive and the Direct Coombs Test (DCT) is negative to prevent Rh sensitization and protect future pregnancies.

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by facial palsy due to herpes infection involving the geniculate ganglion? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is characterized by facial palsy due to herpes zoster infection (varicella-zoster virus) involving the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve. It presents as a triad of facial nerve palsy, vesicular eruptions on the pinna and external auditory canal, and vestibulocochlear symptoms. The infection represents a reactivation of the herpes zoster virus that had remained dormant in the geniculate ganglion after previous chickenpox infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heerfordt Syndrome: This is a rare manifestation of sarcoidosis characterized by the triad of uveitis, parotid gland enlargement, and facial nerve palsy. It is not related to herpes infection of the geniculate ganglion. The facial palsy in this condition is due to granulomatous infiltration of the facial nerve.

 

Option C. Bell's Palsy: While this is also a facial nerve paralysis, Bell's palsy is idiopathic in nature. Although some theories suggest that herpes simplex virus may be involved in some cases of Bell's palsy, it does not specifically involve vesicular eruptions or definitive evidence of geniculate ganglion involvement as seen in Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

 

Option D. Melkersson's Syndrome: This syndrome (also called Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome) is characterized by recurrent or persistent facial swelling, recurrent facial paralysis, and a fissured tongue (lingua plicata). It is not caused by herpes infection of the geniculate ganglion but is thought to be related to granulomatous disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is specifically characterized by facial nerve palsy due to herpes zoster infection of the geniculate ganglion, presenting with the distinctive triad of facial paralysis, ear/mouth vesicles, and auditory/vestibular symptoms.

questions.text: Identify the incision made and marked is the image: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gibson 

 

  • The Gibson incision is correct in this scenario, assuming the surgical mark and procedure are aimed at accessing structures in the lower quadrant of the abdomen or the pelvis. This incision provides the necessary exposure while minimizing damage to the muscular and nerve structures

 

This is a type of oblique incision made along the line of the inguinal ligament. It is primarily used for procedures involving the lower ureter, pelvic kidney, or bladder surgery. It provides excellent exposure to the lower abdomen and pelvic areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robson Incision: This is also known as the "classic gridiron" incision. It's a muscle-splitting incision used primarily for accessing the appendix during an appendectomy. It runs obliquely in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.

 

Option B. Battle Incision: Less commonly referenced, this incision isn't widely recognized in standard surgical texts under this name. It may refer to a specialized or less commonly used approach.

 

Option D. Kocher Incision: This incision is typically used for biliary surgery. It is a subcostal incision made parallel to the costal margin, usually on the right side, to provide access to the gallbladder and biliary tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gibson Incision is a type of oblique incision made along the line of the inguinal ligament. It is primarily used for procedures involving the lower ureter, pelvic kidney, or bladder surgery

questions.text: Which of these is used for immediate reversal of Vecuronium in a patient for normal kidney function? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sugammadex

 

Sugammadex is a selective relaxant binding agent / cyclodextrin molecule used to reverse the effects of certain non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents, particularly rocuronium and vecuronium. It works by encapsulating the vecuronium molecule, thereby rendering it inactive and allowing for rapid reversal of muscle paralysis. Sugammadex is particularly advantageous in cases where quick recovery from neuromuscular blockade is required, and it is effective in patients with normal kidney function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used primarily to reverse the effects of anticholinergic toxicity. It is not used to reverse neuromuscular blockade caused by vecuronium.

 

Option C. Rivastigmine: Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia. It has no role in reversing neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine: Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant used to induce short-term paralysis, typically for intubation. It is not used to reverse the effects of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers like vecuronium; rather, it is itself a paralytic agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sugammadex is the drug of choice for the immediate reversal of vecuronium-induced neuromuscular blockade

questions.text: What is a common element of both the medial and lateral plantar arches? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b) Plantar fascia

 

Explanation:

 

The plantar fascia is a common element supporting both the medial and lateral longitudinal arches of the foot. This thick, fibrous band of tissue extends from the calcaneal tuberosity anteriorly to the metatarsal heads, serving as a crucial passive support structure. The plantar fascia acts like a bowstring, tensing during weight-bearing to maintain both longitudinal arches. When the toes are extended, it tightens through the windlass mechanism, increasing arch height and providing stability to both medial and lateral aspects of the foot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Flexor digitorum brevis - This muscle primarily supports the medial longitudinal arch rather than both arches. It originates from the medial tubercle of the calcaneus and inserts into the middle phalanges of the lateral four toes.

 

Option C) Spring ligament (plantar calcaneonavicular ligament) - This ligament specifically supports the head of the talus and the medial longitudinal arch. It does not contribute significantly to the lateral arch support.

 

Option D) Deltoid ligament - This ligament attaches to the medial malleolus of the tibia and provides medial stability to the ankle joint. While it helps support the medial arch, it has minimal contribution to the lateral arch.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The plantar fascia is a critical passive support structure for both the medial and lateral longitudinal arches of the foot, functioning as a tension band that provides dynamic support during weight-bearing and movement.

questions.text: Which structure passes posterior to the hilum of the lung? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a) Vagus nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The vagus nerve passes posterior to the hilum of the lung. The relations of the root of the lung include both anterior and posterior structures. Posteriorly, the vagus nerve and posterior pulmonary plexus are located behind the hilum. The vagus nerve descends through the thorax, contributing to the formation of the posterior pulmonary plexus, which supplies the bronchial tree and lung tissue. After passing behind the root of the lung, the vagus nerve continues downward to help form the esophageal plexus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phrenic nerve: The phrenic nerve runs anterior to the root of the lung, not posterior. It descends between the fibrous pericardium and mediastinal pleura to supply the diaphragm. It is accompanied by the pericardiacophrenic vessels.

 

Option C. Superior vena cava (SVC): The SVC is located anterior and to the right of the trachea and does not pass posterior to the hilum of the lung. It forms part of the anterior relations of the right lung hilum.

 

Option D. Right atrium: The right atrium forms part of the mediastinal surface impression on the right lung but is anterior to the hilum, not posterior. It has no relation to the posterior aspect of the lung hilum.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The vagus nerve passes posterior to the hilum of the lung, contributing to the posterior pulmonary plexus before continuing downward to form the esophageal plexus.

questions.text: Which one of the following leads to shift toward red curve in the given graph? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acidosis

 

Explanation: 

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (OHDC) shows the relationship between PO2 and hemoglobin saturation. The red curve in the image represents a right shift. Acidosis causes a right shift of the curve, known as the Bohr effect. When blood pH decreases (acidosis), the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen decreases, causing more oxygen to be released to the tissues. This is physiologically beneficial as tissues in acidotic conditions often need more oxygen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Less 2,3 BPG: Incorrect Less 2,3-BPG causes a left shift of the curve, not right

 

  • When 2,3-BPG levels decrease, hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen increases
  • This means oxygen binds more tightly to hemoglobin and less is released to tissues

 

Option C. Hypocarbia: Incorrect Hypocarbia means decreased CO2 levels

 

  • This leads to alkalosis which causes a left shift
  • Results in increased affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen

 

Option D. Hypothermia: Incorrect Lower temperature causes a left shift of the curve

 

  • Increases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen
  • Reduces oxygen delivery to tissues

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acidosis causes a right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (Bohr effect), while alkalosis, hypothermia, and decreased 2,3-BPG cause left shifts.

questions.text: Basiocciput fuses with basisphenoid at what age? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 18-22 years

 

The fusion of the basiocciput with the basisphenoid occurs at around 18-22 years of age. This process is part of the normal skeletal development during late adolescence and early adulthood.

 

Fusion Age: The fusion of these bones is a significant event in the maturation of the cranial base, occurring between the ages of 18 and 22 years. This fusion helps in the formation of a solid and stable base for the skull.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fusion of Basiocciput with basisphenoid is seen around 18-22 years.

questions.text: Identify the condition according to given image below.(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trophic ulcer

 

  • Image given is of trophic ulcer, typically seen in diabetic patients because of lack of sensation.
  • They are seen on weight bearing parts of foot.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trophic ulcers, commonly seen in diabetic patients, are typically found on weight-bearing parts of the foot and are characterized by their punched-out appearance with hyperkeratotic edges and undermined borders.
  • They are primarily caused by peripheral neuropathy, leading to a lack of sensation in the affected areas. Proper foot care and regular inspection are crucial in preventing these ulcers.

questions.text: What type of transporter is found in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Na+ –2Cl– -K+ cotransporter

 

Explanation:


In the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, the Na+ K+ 2Cl- transporter (NKC or NKCC) is the primary transport mechanism located on the apical side of the cells. This cotransporter simultaneously moves 1 Na+, 1 K+, and 2 Cl- ions from the tubular lumen into the cell. This transport system is critically important for the creation of the medullary concentration gradient and is the site of action for loop diuretics.

The thick ascending limb contains ROMK channels on the apical side that secrete K+ back into the lumen, and Na+ K+ ATPase channels and Cl- channels (ClC-Kb) on the basal side that move ions into the bloodstream. The Cl- channels require Barttin protein for activation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Na+ Cl+ cotransporter - This transporter (NCC) is found in the distal convoluted tubule, not the thick ascending limb. Thiazide diuretics block this transporter, and mutations in this transporter result in Gitelman syndrome.
  • Option c. ENaC channel - This is the epithelial sodium channel found in the collecting duct and distal tubule (principal cells), not the thick ascending limb. It is regulated by aldosterone and blocked by amiloride.
  • Option d. Na+ -amino acid cotransporter - This type of cotransporter is found in the proximal convoluted tubule where amino acid reabsorption occurs, not in the thick ascending limb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thick ascending limb's unique Na+ K+ 2Cl- cotransporter is key for the kidney's concentrating ability and creates the medullary osmotic gradient necessary for water reabsorption in the collecting ducts.

questions.text: A child presented with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cretinism

 

The child presents with symptoms that are highly characteristic of congenital hypothyroidism, also known as cretinism. These symptoms include dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia (enlarged tongue), and umbilical hernia. Congenital hypothyroidism is a condition that arises from insufficient thyroid hormone production at birth. If untreated, it can lead to mental retardation and developmental delays. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent long-term adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prader-Willi syndrome: This genetic disorder is characterized by hypotonia, feeding difficulties in infancy, followed by hyperphagia and obesity in childhood, intellectual disability, and characteristic facial features. It does not typically present with macroglossia or umbilical hernia.

 

Option C. Edward syndrome: Also known as Trisomy 18, Edward syndrome presents with severe intellectual disability, congenital heart defects, and distinct facial features. While it can present with a range of symptoms, dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia are not typical features.

 

Option D. Galactosemia: This metabolic disorder is due to an inability to metabolize galactose properly. Symptoms include jaundice, vomiting, poor weight gain, and lethargy. It does not typically present with macroglossia, dry skin, or rough hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cretinism, or congenital hypothyroidism, should be considered in infants presenting with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent long-term developmental delays.

questions.text: A factory worker is exposed to phosphine gas during a pesticide fumigation process. He develops nausea, vomiting, dyspnea, and hypotension. Phosphine gas primarily causes which type of hypoxia? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histotoxic

 

Explanation:

 

Phosphine gas causes histotoxic hypoxia by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase activity in the tissues. This leads to:

 

  • Decreased oxygen uptake by the tissues
  • Reduced mitochondrial function
  • Inability of cells to utilize available oxygen
  • Normal oxygen content in blood but tissues cannot use it
  • Results in cellular hypoxia despite adequate oxygen delivery

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaemic Hypoxia: Incorrect

 

  • Occurs due to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of blood
  • Normal alveolar oxygen but reduced hemoglobin or abnormal hemoglobin
  • Examples: Anemia, CO poisoning, methemoglobinemia
  • Not relevant here as phosphine doesn't affect hemoglobin

 

Option B. Hypoxic Hypoxia: Incorrect

 

  • Results from low atmospheric partial pressure of oxygen
  • Reduced oxygen gradient towards alveoli and pulmonary capillaries
  • Examples: High altitude, diffusion disorders, fibrosis
  • Phosphine doesn't affect atmospheric or alveolar oxygen levels

 

Option D. Stagnant Hypoxia: Incorrect

 

  • Due to reduced blood flow/circulation
  • Normal atmospheric oxygen, alveoli, and hemoglobin
  • Occurs in circulatory failure
  • Phosphine primarily affects cellular oxygen utilization, not circulation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphine gas causes histotoxic hypoxia by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase in the mitochondria, preventing cellular oxygen utilization despite normal oxygen delivery to tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is NOT innervated by the superior gluteal nerve? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b. Gluteus maximus

 

Explanation:

 

The superior gluteal nerve innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles. Gluteus maximus is instead innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve. The superior gluteal nerve arises from the sacral plexus (L4, L5, S1) and exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle. It then runs between the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles and supplies both these muscles along with the tensor fasciae latae.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gluteus medius - This muscle is correctly innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. It functions primarily as a hip abductor and helps stabilize the pelvis during walking.

 

Option C. Gluteus minimus - This is indeed supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Like the gluteus medius, it acts as a hip abductor and medial rotator of the thigh.

 

Option D. Tensor fasciae latae - This muscle receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. It functions to tense the fascia lata and assists in hip flexion, abduction, and medial rotation.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1) innervates three muscles: gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae, while the gluteus maximus receives its innervation from the inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2).

questions.text: FSH is inhibited by: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibin

 

Explanation: 

 

FSH is inhibited by inhibin. This is a direct feedback mechanism where:

 

  • Inhibin is produced by the gonads (Sertoli cells in males and granulosa cells in females)
  • It specifically inhibits FSH secretion from the anterior pituitary
  • This creates a negative feedback loop that helps regulate FSH levels

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estrogen Incorrect because estrogen is stimulated by FSH, not the other way around. FSH stimulates estrogen production from ovarian follicles.

 

Option C. Progesterone Incorrect because progesterone doesn't directly inhibit FSH. While progesterone can affect the hypothalamic-pituitary axis, it's not the primary inhibitor of FSH.

 

Option D. Testosterone Incorrect because testosterone doesn't directly inhibit FSH. While testosterone can affect the hypothalamic-pituitary axis through negative feedback, it's not the primary inhibitor of FSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibin is the primary and specific inhibitor of FSH secretion from the anterior pituitary gland.

questions.text: Which one of the following is related to the release of bicarbonate in exchange of Chloride in the RBC? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloride shift

 

Explanation: 

 

Chloride shift (also known as Hamburger phenomenon) occurs when RBCs move towards the tissue. As RBCs enter venous blood, CO2 diffuses into them and combines with H2O to form H2CO3 under the influence of carbonic anhydrase. H2CO3 dissociates into H+ and HCO3-. The bicarbonate ion is then exchanged for chloride through an exchanger protein. When chloride enters the RBC, water follows due to osmosis, causing the RBCs to swell. This increases the hematocrit in venous blood compared to arterial blood.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bohr's effect: Incorrect. Because Bohr's effect refers to the right shift of oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve due to increased CO2, decreased pH, or increased temperature, leading to enhanced oxygen unloading in tissues.

 

Option B. Haldane effect: Incorrect. Because Haldane effect describes the enhanced unloading of CO2 in the lungs due to increased oxygenation of hemoglobin. It represents the left shift of the curve in lungs.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect. Because chloride shift is the correct phenomenon describing the exchange of bicarbonate and chloride in RBCs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chloride shift (Hamburger phenomenon) involves the exchange of bicarbonate ions for chloride ions across the RBC membrane during tissue gas exchange, leading to increased RBC volume in venous blood.

questions.text: The most common site of acute limb ischemia from an embolic event is: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Femoral Bifurcation

 

Explanation:

 

The femoral bifurcation is the most common site of acute limb ischemia from embolic events. Emboli typically originate from cardiac sources such as left atrial thrombus in atrial fibrillation or mural thrombus following myocardial infarction. These emboli travel through the arterial system until they lodge at points where vessels narrow significantly, with the femoral bifurcation being a prime location for emboli to become trapped.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorto-iliac Bifurcation: While emboli at this location cause dramatic symptoms affecting both lower limbs simultaneously, they are less common than femoral emboli. Aortic bifurcation emboli typically cause bilateral symptoms with severe ischemia.

 

Option C. Popliteal Trifurcation: This is a more distal site where smaller emboli might lodge. While popliteal emboli do occur, they are less frequent than femoral emboli in acute limb ischemia presentations.

 

Option D. Brachial Artery: Upper extremity emboli are significantly less common than lower extremity emboli. The anatomical pathway from common cardiac sources naturally directs most emboli toward the lower limbs rather than the upper limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Embolic occlusions most frequently occur at the femoral bifurcation, presenting as unilateral acute limb ischemia with the classic signs: pain, pallor, pulselessness, paresthesia, and paralysis.

questions.text: Which mineral is important for sexual maturation? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Zinc

 

Explanation:

 

Zinc is the mineral most crucial for sexual maturation. It plays a significant role in several biological processes related to growth and development, particularly in the reproductive system. Zinc is essential for the stabilization of cell membranes and has anti-inflammatory properties. Moreover, zinc is crucial for the proper functioning and development of sperm, which directly links it to sexual maturation.

 

One of the key reasons zinc is important in sexual maturation is because of its role in the formation of zinc finger motifs. These motifs are a type of protein structure that binds to DNA and plays a vital role in gene expression, including genes involved in the development of sexual characteristics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selenium: Selenium is an essential trace element that plays a role in antioxidant defense and thyroid function. While it is important for general health, it is not as directly involved in sexual maturation as zinc.

 

Option B. Copper: Copper is important for various enzymatic reactions and the formation of red blood cells. Although it contributes to overall health, it is not specifically linked to sexual maturation.

 

Option C. Calcium: Calcium is critical for bone health and muscle function, but it does not have a direct role in sexual maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc is the key mineral necessary for sexual maturation, particularly due to its role in the development and functioning of the reproductive system, including the formation of zinc finger motifs important for gene expression

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

D. Mitochondrial - 1. LHON (Leber's Hereditary Optic Neuropathy):

LHON is caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA affecting the optic nerve and leading to vision loss.

 

A. AD (Autosomal Dominant) - 2. Myotonic Dystrophy:

Myotonic Dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by muscle wasting and myotonia, caused by an expanded repeat sequence in the DMPK gene.

 

B. AR (Autosomal recessive) 3. Cystic Fibrosis:

Cystic Fibrosis is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, affecting the respiratory and digestive systems.

 

C. XR (X-Linked Recessive) 4. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy:

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the DMD gene, leading to progressive muscle degeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Different genetic disorders are inherited through various modes of inheritance: autosomal dominant (e.g., Myotonic Dystrophy), autosomal recessive (e.g., Cystic Fibrosis), X-linked recessive (e.g., Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy), and mitochondrial (e.g., LHON).

questions.text: Match the following muscles with their action at shoulder joint: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

A. Latissimus dorsi: This muscle is known as the "stand at ease" muscle, the "climbers muscle," and the "swimmers muscle." It originates from the back and inserts into the front between two major muscles. When it contracts, it causes backward movement, extension, adduction, and medial rotation of the shoulder. Therefore, its action is extension with medial rotation (Action 2).

 

B. Supraspinatus: Located above the spine of the scapula, the supraspinatus muscle, when it contracts, moves the arm away from the midline, which is known as abduction. Hence, its action is abduction (Action 3).

 

C. Infraspinatus: This muscle originates from the back and rotates the arm outward when it contracts, causing lateral rotation. Thus, its action is lateral rotation (Action 4).

 

D. Pectoralis Major (sternal head): Originating from the midline (sternum and clavicle) and inserting into the lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus, this muscle, when contracted, causes movement to the front (flexion). Therefore, its action is flexion (Action 1).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Latissimus dorsi is responsible for extension with medial rotation.
  • Supraspinatus is responsible for abduction.
  • Infraspinatus is responsible for lateral rotation.
  • Pectoralis Major (sternal head) is responsible for flexion.
